items.text: I never reveal my true intentions until the moment is right.
items.rationale: Strategic concealment of motives is a hallmark of Machiavellianism, reflecting calculated self-presentation and long-term planning.

items.text: Most people are pawns in a game they don't even know they're playing.
items.rationale: Cynical worldview combined with a sense of strategic superiority is core to Machiavellian cognition.

items.text: I carefully study people's weaknesses because you never know when that information will be useful.
items.rationale: Deliberate intelligence-gathering about others' vulnerabilities for future exploitation is a defining Machiavellian behavior.

items.text: Flattery is a tool, and I know exactly how to use it.
items.rationale: Instrumental use of ingratiation and impression management reflects the strategic interpersonal manipulation central to Machiavellianism.

items.text: I believe that forming alliances is more important than forming friendships.
items.rationale: Prioritizing strategic utility over genuine emotional connection reflects the transactional relationship orientation of Machiavellianism.

items.text: People who trust others too easily are practically asking to be taken advantage of.
items.rationale: Cynical view of trust and interpersonal naivety is a core cognitive feature of Machiavellianism.

items.text: I always have a backup plan in case someone tries to double-cross me.
items.rationale: Anticipatory distrust and contingency planning reflect the paranoid strategic thinking characteristic of Machiavellianism.

items.text: It's wise to keep certain people close not because you like them, but because they're useful.
items.rationale: Maintaining instrumental relationships based on utility rather than affection is a classic Machiavellian interpersonal strategy.

items.text: I've been told I'm good at getting people to do things without them realizing I'm behind it.
items.rationale: Covert influence and behind-the-scenes manipulation are behavioral signatures of Machiavellianism.

items.text: The ends justify the means, especially when the stakes are high.
items.rationale: Consequentialist moral reasoning that permits ethically questionable tactics is a defining philosophical stance of Machiavellianism.

items.text: I prefer to let others show their cards first before I make my move.
items.rationale: Strategic patience and information asymmetry exploitation are core tactical behaviors in Machiavellianism.

items.text: In negotiations, I always aim to know more about the other person than they know about me.
items.rationale: Deliberate cultivation of informational advantage in interpersonal exchanges is a hallmark Machiavellian tactic.

items.text: I sometimes pretend to agree with people just to keep the peace until I can get what I want.
items.rationale: While clearly strategic and deceptive, surface-level agreeableness for self-serving purposes could also reflect conflict avoidance; however, the instrumental motive anchors it to Machiavellianism.

items.text: I find it easy to switch between being charming and being cold, depending on what the situation requires.
items.rationale: Emotional flexibility in service of goals is Machiavellian, but the shallow affect and charm could also suggest psychopathic traits.

items.text: I enjoy the feeling of pulling strings behind the scenes and watching things unfold according to my plan.
items.rationale: The enjoyment of control and orchestration is Machiavellian, but the pleasure derived from power and superiority could also reflect grandiose narcissistic satisfaction.

items.text: I deserve recognition that most people around me fail to give.
items.rationale: A sense of unmet entitlement and perceived under-recognition are core features of grandiose narcissism.

items.text: When I walk into a room, I naturally expect to be the center of attention.
items.rationale: Expectation of admiration and social centrality is a defining behavioral manifestation of narcissistic grandiosity.

items.text: I often fantasize about achieving great things that will make everyone admire me.
items.rationale: Grandiose fantasies of success and admiration are a DSM-consistent criterion for narcissistic personality features.

items.text: People who criticize me are usually just jealous of what I've accomplished.
items.rationale: Externalizing criticism as envy is a classic narcissistic defense mechanism that protects the inflated self-image.

items.text: I honestly believe I am more talented than most of the people I meet.
items.rationale: Inflated self-appraisal and superiority beliefs are central to the grandiose self-concept in narcissism.

items.text: I get deeply irritated when someone doesn't acknowledge my contributions.
items.rationale: Narcissistic injury from perceived lack of recognition reflects the fragile self-esteem and entitlement underlying narcissism.

items.text: I have a special quality that sets me apart from ordinary people.
items.rationale: Belief in one's own uniqueness and specialness is a core narcissistic cognition consistent with DSM criteria.

items.text: I tend to surround myself with people who appreciate how exceptional I am.
items.rationale: Seeking admiring audiences and narcissistic supply through selective social affiliation is a hallmark narcissistic interpersonal pattern.

items.text: Others have described me as someone who talks about myself too much.
items.rationale: Third-person behavioral observation of excessive self-referential speech reflects the self-absorption characteristic of narcissism.

items.text: I feel that rules and expectations that apply to others shouldn't necessarily apply to someone like me.
items.rationale: Sense of exemption from ordinary rules reflects narcissistic entitlement and grandiose self-perception.

items.text: I can't stand being in a group where someone else is getting all the praise.
items.rationale: Competitive envy and intolerance of others' recognition reflect narcissistic rivalry and threatened grandiosity.

items.text: I know I'm destined for greatness, even if others can't see it yet.
items.rationale: Grandiose future-oriented self-belief despite lack of external validation is a core narcissistic fantasy.

items.text: I sometimes exaggerate my achievements to make sure people understand how capable I am.
items.rationale: Self-enhancement through exaggeration is narcissistic, but the deliberate impression management could also have a Machiavellian strategic quality.

items.text: I find it hard to genuinely celebrate other people's successes because I feel I deserve that success more.
items.rationale: Envy and competitive self-comparison are narcissistic, though the lack of empathic joy could also suggest reduced affective empathy seen in psychopathy.

items.text: I use my charm and charisma to make sure I always come out on top in social situations.
items.rationale: While narcissistic charm serves self-aggrandizement, the instrumental use of charm to 'come out on top' also strongly resembles Machiavellian strategic self-presentation.

items.text: I don't feel guilty about things that other people seem to agonize over.
items.rationale: Deficient guilt and remorse relative to social norms is a core affective deficit in psychopathy.

items.text: When someone is upset, I understand intellectually what they're feeling, but I don't actually feel it myself.
items.rationale: Intact cognitive empathy with deficient affective empathy is a well-established hallmark of psychopathic personality.

items.text: I've done things that most people would consider reckless, but I found them thrilling.
items.rationale: Sensation-seeking and thrill-seeking despite risk are core behavioral features of psychopathy linked to fearlessness and impulsivity.

items.text: I can lie to someone's face without feeling the slightest bit uncomfortable.
items.rationale: Pathological lying with absence of autonomic discomfort reflects the shallow affect and deceitfulness central to psychopathy.

items.text: I tend to act on impulse without worrying about the consequences.
items.rationale: Impulsivity and failure to consider consequences are core behavioral features of the lifestyle/antisocial facet of psychopathy.

items.text: Seeing other people in emotional pain doesn't really affect me the way it seems to affect others.
items.rationale: Callousness and reduced empathic distress in response to others' suffering is a defining affective feature of psychopathy.

items.text: I've been told I can be cruel, but I honestly don't see what the big deal is.
items.rationale: Callous disregard for the impact of one's behavior on others, combined with lack of insight, reflects core psychopathic callous-unemotional traits.

items.text: I get bored very easily and need constant stimulation to feel alive.
items.rationale: Proneness to boredom and need for stimulation are established facets of psychopathy on the PCL-R and related measures.

items.text: I don't really form deep emotional attachments to other people.
items.rationale: Shallow affect and inability to form genuine emotional bonds are core interpersonal-affective features of psychopathy.

items.text: If hurting someone's feelings gets me what I need, I won't lose sleep over it.
items.rationale: Instrumental harm with absence of remorse reflects the callous and exploitative interpersonal style of psychopathy.

items.text: I've broken promises many times and it has never really bothered me.
items.rationale: Irresponsibility and lack of guilt over broken commitments reflect the antisocial lifestyle and deficient conscience characteristic of psychopathy.

items.text: People have called me cold-hearted, and honestly, they're probably right.
items.rationale: Self-acknowledged emotional coldness with ego-syntonic acceptance is consistent with the callous-unemotional presentation of psychopathy.

items.text: I can turn my emotions on and off like a switch when I need to.
items.rationale: Emotional detachment and volitional affect regulation suggest psychopathic shallow affect, though strategic emotional control also has Machiavellian overtones.

items.text: I enjoy having power over people and seeing them do what I want.
items.rationale: Dominance motivation and interpersonal exploitation are psychopathic, but the enjoyment of power could also reflect narcissistic grandiosity or Machiavellian control.

items.text: I'm willing to say whatever people want to hear if it serves my purposes, and I feel nothing about it afterward.
items.rationale: The strategic deception is Machiavellian in nature, but the explicit absence of guilt or emotional residue anchors it toward psychopathy; the boundary lies in the calculated, purposeful quality of the deception.
